task.title: Reusable Steps
task.shortdesc: You can conref these steps. Don't change anything in this file without checking where it is used.

cmd.draft-comment: The following two step are used in Configuring a Pipeline and the tutorial pipeline config topic.

step.cmd: From the Home page or Getting Started page, click Create New Pipeline.

info.note: To get to the Home page, click the Home icon.

step.cmd: In the New Pipeline window, enter a pipeline title and optional description, and select where you want the pipeline to run:

choices.choice: - Select to design a standalone or cluster execution mode pipeline that runs on .
- Select to design an edge execution mode pipeline that runs on .

step.cmd: Click Save.
step.stepresult: The pipeline canvas displays the pipeline title, the generated pipeline ID, and an error icon. The error icon indicates that you need to configure error handling for the pipeline. The Properties panel displays the pipeline properties.

cmd.draft-comment: The steps below are for data preview. They are used in "Previewing a Single Stage" and "Previewing Multiple Stages."

step.cmd: Above the pipeline canvas, click the Preview icon: .
step.info: If the Preview icon is disabled, check the Issues list for unconnected stages and required properties that are not defined.

step.cmd: In the Preview Configuration dialog box, configure the following properties, then click Run Preview.

row.entry:
Source data for the preview:
Configured Source - Provides data from the origin system.
Snapshot Data - Uses available snapshot data.

Number of records to use in the preview. Honors values up to the preview batch size.
Default is 10. The default is 10.
Milliseconds to wait for preview data. Use to limit the time data preview waits for data to arrive at the origin. Relevant for transient origins only.

Determines whether the preview passes data to destinations or executors.
By default, does not pass data to destination or executor stages.
Triggers the generation of any appropriate pipeline events, typically the Start event. If the event is configured to be used, event consumption is also triggered.
Displays record header attributes and field attributes when in List view. Attributes do not display in Table view.
Displays the data type for fields in List view. Field types do not display in Table view.
When using a snapshot for source data, select the snapshot to use.

Stores the current preview configuration for use every time you request a preview for this pipeline.
After you run data preview, you can change this option in the Preview panel by selecting the Preview Configuration icon () and clearing the option. The change takes effect the next time you run data preview.

step.stepresult:
The Preview panel highlights the origin stage and displays preview data in table view. Since this is the origin of the pipeline, no input data displays.
To view preview data in list view, click the List View icon: .

step.cmd: To delete a record that you do not want to use, click the Delete icon.
To refresh the preview, click the Refresh Preview icon: .
step.info: Based on the origin, refreshing the preview either provides a new set of data or reverts any changes to the existing data.

step.cmd: To exit data preview and return to pipeline configuration, click Close Preview.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used in "Previewing a Single Stage" and "Reviewing Snapshot Data"

step.cmd: To view data for the next stage, click the Next Stage icon. Or, to view data for a different stage, select the stage in the pipeline canvas.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStepErrorHandling - Use this step for origins that are not cluster origins. Standalone only

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-ClusterOrigin - Use for origins that ARE cluster origins - points out stop pipeline is not valid.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-StageLib-EHandling - Use this step for non-cluster origins with stage libraries.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVROFILE - The following step is used by any file-based origin that reads from Avro and includes compression – Should be S3, Directory, File Tail, Kinesis Consumer origin? Origins that do not include compression conref rows from here. – Hadoop FS,

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when processing data:
Message/Data Includes Schema - Use the schema in the file.
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema provided in the stage configuration.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.
Using a schema in the stage configuration or in the Confluent Schema Registry can improve performance.

Avro schema definition used to process the data. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.
Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data.

Avro schema subject to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVRO-Mess - The following step is used by origins that read Avro data from messages and have compression. Kinesis Consumer. Origins without compression uses rows - JMS, Kafka.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when processing data:
Message/Data Includes Schema - Use the schema in the message.
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema provided in the stage configuration.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.
Using a schema in the stage configuration or in the Confluent Schema Registry can improve performance.

Avro schema definition used to process the data. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.
Embedded Schema ID - Look up the Avro schema ID embedded in each message. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the message.

Avro schema subject to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.

cmd.draft-comment: O-AVRO-KAFKA used by Kafka Consumer

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when processing data:
Message/Data Includes Schema - Use the schema in the message.
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema provided in the stage configuration.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.
Using a schema in the stage configuration or in the Confluent Schema Registry can improve performance.

Avro schema definition used to process the data. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.
Embedded Schema ID - Look up the Avro schema ID embedded in each message. You must configure the origin to use the Confluent method to deserialize the messages on the Kafka tab. Overrides any existing schema definitions associated with the message.

Avro schema subject to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.

Method used to deserialize the Kafka message key.
Set to Confluent when the Avro schema ID is embedded in each Kafka message.

Method used to deserialize the Kafka message value.
Set to Confluent when the Avro schema ID is embedded in each Kafka message.

cmd.draft-comment: O-Binary . Used by message reading origins that have compression - Kinesis Consumer, Redis Consumer. Non-compressed origins use rows - JMS, Kafka

step.cmd: For binary data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Maximum number of bytes in the message. Larger messages cannot be processed or written to error.

cmd.draft-comment: O-Datagram - Kafka Consumer, WebSocket Server, WebSocket Client, COaP Server, HTTP Server, MQTT Subscriber

step.cmd: For datagram data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

entry.p: For collectd data only.
For collectd data only.
For collectd data only.
For collectd data only.
For NetFlow 9 data only.
For NetFlow 9 data only.
For NetFlow 9 data only.

cmd.draft-comment: DELIMITED data - Step used by Delimited origins using compression – S3, Directory, Other Delimited origins use steps. - Hadoop FS origin, JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer

step.cmd: For delimited data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Delimiter format type. Use one of the following options:
Indicates whether a file contains a header line, and whether to use the header line.
When processing data with a header line, allows processing records with more columns than exist in the header line.

Prefix to use for any additional columns. Extra columns are named using the prefix and sequential increasing integers as follows: <prefix><integer>.
For example, _extra_1. Default is _extra_.
Maximum length of a record in characters. Longer records are not read.

Delimiter character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
You can enter a Unicode control character using the format \uNNNN, where ​N is a hexadecimal digit from the numbers 0-9 or the letters A-F. For example, enter \u0000 to use the null character as the delimiter or \u2028 to use a line separator as the delimiter.
Default is the pipe character ( | ).
Escape character for a custom file type.
Quote character for a custom file type.

Root field type to use:
List-Map - Generates an indexed list of data. Enables you to use standard functions to process data. Use for new pipelines.
List - Generates a record with an indexed list with a map for header and value. Requires the use of delimited data functions to process data. Use only to maintain pipelines created before 1.1.0.
Lines to skip before reading data.
Replaces the specified string constant with null values.
String constant to replace with null values.

cmd.draft-comment: JSON-2props - Kafka Consumer, Kinesis all use them. HTTP Client, and probably others use the 2nd row. Non compression origins use rows - JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer

step.cmd: For JSON data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Type of JSON content. Use one of the following options:
Array of Objects
Multiple Objects

Maximum number of characters in a JSON object.
Longer objects are diverted to the pipeline for error handling.

cmd.draft-comment: LOG data - Used in JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer, Hadoop FS, probably Directory. Use the following for origins that use the Log data format. UL in first row is also being conrefed in Log Parser.
Also - For any changes to the bullets below this first table, update Log Parser as well. Everything except the Log4j table/bullet point is copied from here.

step.cmd: For log data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Format of the log files. Use one of the following options:
Common Log Format
Combined Log Format
Apache Error Log Format
Apache Access Log Custom Format
Regular Expression
Grok Pattern
Log4j
Maximum length of a log line. The origin truncates longer lines.

Determines how to treat the original log line. Select to include the original log line as a field in the resulting record.
By default, the original line is discarded.

ul.li: When you select Apache Access Log Custom Format, use Apache log format strings to define the Custom Log Format.
When you select Regular Expression, enter the regular expression that describes the log format, and then map the fields that you want to include to each regular expression group.

When you select Grok Pattern, you can use the Grok Pattern Definition field to define custom grok patterns. You can define a pattern on each line.
In the Grok Pattern field, enter the pattern to use to parse the log. You can use a predefined grok patterns or create a custom grok pattern using patterns defined in Grok Pattern Definition.
For more information about defining grok patterns and supported grok patterns, see .

When you select Log4j, define the following properties:
Log4j Property Description
On Parse Error Determines how to handle information that cannot be parsed:
Skip and Log Error - Skips reading the line and logs a stage error.
Skip, No Error - Skips reading the line and does not log an error.
Include as Stack Trace - Includes information that cannot be parsed as a stack trace to the previously-read log line. The information is added to the message field for the last valid log line.
Use Custom Log Format Allows you to define a custom log format.
Custom Format Use log4j variables to define a custom log format.

cmd.draft-comment:
O-PROTO-Mess. Step used by message-reading stages except for Kafka. Kafka conrefs the first two rows of table.
NOTE: When making changes, make sure to update the file version and destination versions, as necessary.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when reading data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.
Indicates if a message might include more than one protobuf message.

cmd.draft-comment:
O-Proto-File. Step used by file-based proto.
NOTE: When making changes, make sure to update the message version and destination versions, as necessary.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when reading data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.
Indicates if a file might include more than one protobuf message.

cmd.draft-comment: O-SDCRecord - Adding to origins that use it. Non-compression origins use rows.

step.cmd: For SDC Record data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

cmd.draft-comment: TEXT_Hadoop data - Hadoop FS and MapR FS origins (Include Custom Delimiter is not applicable) – should this go in Local FS too?

step.cmd: For text data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Maximum number of characters allowed for a line. Longer lines are truncated.
Adds a boolean field to the record to indicate if it was truncated. The field name is Truncated.
Uses custom delimiters to define records instead of line breaks.
One or more characters to use to define records.

cmd.draft-comment: TEXT data - Amazon S3, Directory, Kafka Consumer, Kinesis Consumer, JMS Consumer. HTTP Client. WebSocket Client. Non compression origins using rows - JMS

step.cmd: For text data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Maximum number of characters allowed for a line. Longer lines are truncated.
Adds a boolean field to the record to indicate if it was truncated. The field name is Truncated.
Uses custom delimiters to define records instead of line breaks.
One or more characters to use to define records.
Includes delimiter characters in the record.

cmd.draft-comment: O-WholeFile - Directory

step.cmd: For whole files on the Data Format tab, configure the following property:

row.entry: Size of the buffer to use to transfer data.

Transfer rate to use.
Enter a number to specify a rate in bytes per second. Use an expression to specify a rate that uses a different unit of measure per second, e.g. ${5 * MB}. Use -1 to opt out of this property.
By default, the origin does not use a transfer rate.

cmd.draft-comment: O-WholeFile-Checksum - S3

step.cmd: For whole files, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Size of the buffer to use to transfer data.

Transfer rate to use.
Enter a number to specify a rate in bytes per second. Use an expression to specify a rate that uses a different unit of measure per second, e.g. ${5 * MB}. Use -1 to opt out of this property.
By default, the origin does not use a transfer rate.
Verifies the checksum during the read.

cmd.draft-comment: XML data - step used by message and file based origins: Kafka Consumer, Hadoop FS, Kinesis Consumer, Directory, S3, HTTP Client, WebSocket Client, maybe more. Origins without compression uses almost all the rows - JMS Consumer, Kafka Consumer, Rabbit MQ Consumer, Redis Consumer

step.cmd: For XML data, on the XML tab, configure the following properties:

entry.p:
Delimiter to use to generate records. Omit a delimiter to treat the entire XML document as one record. Use one of the following:
An XML element directly under the root element.
Use the XML element name without surrounding angle brackets ( < > ) . For example, msg instead of <msg>.
A simplified XPath expression that specifies the data to use.
Use a simplified XPath expression to access data deeper in the XML document or data that requires a more complex access method.
For more information about valid syntax, see .

row.entry:
Includes the XPath to each parsed XML element and XML attribute in field attributes. Also includes each namespace in an xmlns record header attribute.
When not selected, this information is not included in the record. By default, the property is not selected.

Namespace prefix and URI to use when parsing the XML document. Define namespaces when the XML element being used includes a namespace prefix or when the XPath expression includes namespaces.
For information about using namespaces with an XML element, see .
For information about using namespaces with XPath expressions, see .
Using simple or bulk edit mode, click the Add icon to add additional namespaces.

Includes XML attributes and namespace declarations in the record as field attributes. When not selected, XML attributes and namespace declarations are included in the record as fields. For more information about working with field attributes, see .
By default, the property is not selected.

entry.p: The maximum number of characters in a record. Longer records are diverted to the pipeline for error handling.

cmd.draft-comment: ORIGIN-MIXED REUSE - The following handful of steps are for origin/origin, origin/processor or possibly origin/destination reuse. In alphabetical order.
S3 origins:

step.cmd: On the Advanced tab, optionally configure proxy information:

row.entry:
Seconds to wait for a response before closing the connection.
Default is 10 seconds.
Seconds to wait for a response to a query.

cmd.draft-comment: Amazon S3 and Google Cloud Storage origins:

step.cmd: On the Error Handling tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
The action taken when an error occurs while processing an object:
None - Keeps the object in place.
Archive - Copies or moves the object to another prefix or bucket.
Delete - Deletes the object.
When archiving processed objects, best practice is to also archive objects that cannot be processed.
The action to take when archiving an object that cannot be processed.
Prefix for the objects that cannot be processed.
Bucket for the objects that cannot be processed.

cmd.draft-comment: HTTPClient-Credentials - The following steps are used in HTTP Client origin, processor, and destination Configuring topics:

step.cmd: When using authentication, on the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: User name for basic, digest, or universal authentication.
Password for basic, digest, or universal authentication.

cmd.draft-comment: HTTPClient-Proxy - - The following steps are used in HTTP Client origin, processor, and destination Configuring topics:

step.cmd: To use an HTTP proxy, on the Proxy tab, configure the following properties:

cmd.draft-comment: HTTPClient-SSLTLS - The following steps are used in HTTP Client origin, processor, and destination Configuring topics. Also used in the MQTT Subscriber origin and MQTT Publisher destination configuring topics.

step.cmd: Optionally, on the SSL/TLS tab, configure truststore and keystore details:

info.draft-comment: delete when fully replaced with TLS.

cmd.draft-comment:
The following TLS-All step is used by HTTP Server, HTTP to Kafka, SDC RPC to Kafka. Using Keystore+ rows are: TCP Server, SDC RPC origin.
Using Truststore+ rows are: HTTP Client origin, processor & destination, MQTT consumer & producer, SDC RPC destination, Websocket, write to another pipeline
SunX509 is also a conref'ed ph

step.cmd: To use SSL/TLS, click the TLS tab and configure the following properties:

entry.p: Enables the use of TLS.

row.entry:
The path to the keystore file. Enter an absolute path to the file or a path relative to the resources directory: $SDC_RESOURCES.
By default, no keystore is used.

Type of keystore to use. Use one of the following types:
Java Keystore File (JKS)
PKCS-12 (p12 file)
Default is Java Keystore File (JKS).
Password to the keystore file. A password is optional, but recommended.

The algorithm used to manage the keystore.
Default is SunX509.

The path to the truststore file. Enter an absolute path to the file or a path relative to the resources directory: $SDC_RESOURCES.
By default, no truststore is used.

Type of truststore to use. Use one of the following types:
Java Keystore File (JKS)
PKCS-12 (p12 file)
Default is Java Keystore File (JKS).
Password to the truststore file. A password is optional, but recommended.

The algorithm used to manage the truststore.
Default is SunX509.
Determines the transport layer security (TLS) protocol to use. The default protocol is . To use a different protocol, clear this option.

The TLS protocols to use. To use a protocol other than the default , click the Add icon and enter the protocol name. You can use simple or bulk edit mode to add protocols.Older protocols are not as secure as .

Determines the cipher suite to use when performing the SSL/TLS handshake.
provides a set of cipher suites that it can use by default. For a full list, see .

Cipher suites to use. To use a cipher suite that is not a part of the default set, click the Add icon and enter the name of the cipher suite. You can use simple or bulk edit mode to add cipher suites.
Enter the Java Secure Socket Extension (JSSE) name for the additional cipher suites that you want to use.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used by JDBC Multitable Consumer and certain rows are used by SQL Server Change Tracking.

step.cmd: On the Tables tab, define one or more table configurations. Click the Add icon to define another table configuration.
step.info:
Configure the following properties for each table configuration:
Tables Property
Description
Schema Name Name of the schema to use for this table configuration.
Table Name Pattern
Pattern of the table names to read for this table configuration. Use the SQL LIKE syntax to define the pattern.
Default is the percentage wildcard (%) which matches all tables in the schema.
Table Exclusion Pattern
Pattern of the table names to exclude from being read for this table configuration. Use a Java-based regular expression, or regex, to define the pattern.
Leave empty if you do not need to exclude any tables.
Override Offset Columns
Determines whether to use the primary key or other columns as the offset columns for this table configuration.
Select to override the primary key and define other offset columns. Clear to use the primary key as the offset column.
Initial Offset
Offset value to use for this table configuration when the pipeline starts. Enter the primary key name or offset column name and value. For Datetime columns, enter a Long value.
When you define multiple offset columns, you must define an initial offset value for each column, in the same order that the columns are defined.
Offset Column Conditions
Additional conditions that the origin uses to determine where to start reading data for this table configuration. The origin adds the defined condition to the WHERE clause of the SQL query.
Use the expression language to define the conditions. For example, you can use the offset:column function to compare the value of an offset column.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in JDBC Consumer, JDBC Producer, JDBC Lookup, and JDBC Tee config topics. Oracle CDC Client is using some info from the Credentials table, and the whole Legacy Drivers step.

step.cmd: To enter JDBC credentials separately from the JDBC connection string, on the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: User name for the JDBC connection.

step.cmd: When using JDBC versions older than 4.0, on the Legacy Drivers tab, optionally configure the following properties:

row.entry: Class name for the JDBC driver. Required for JDBC versions older than version 4.0.
Optional query to test the health of a connection. Recommended only when the JDBC version is older than 4.0.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is for JMS origin and rows are used by the JMS Producer.

step.cmd: On the JMS tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
JMS initial context factory.
For example, for Apache ActiveMQ you might use: org.apache.activemq.jndi.ActiveMQInitialContextFactory.
Or for Oracle Weblogic, you might use: weblogic.jndi.WLInitialContextFactory.

JNDI connection factory.
For example, for ActiveMQ, you might use: ConnectionFactory.
For Weblogic, you might use: jms/ConnectionFactory.

URL for the JMS provider.
For example, for ActiveMQ, you might use: tcp://localhost:<portno>.
For Weblogic, you might use: t3/localhost:<portno>.

JMS queue or topic name.
For example, for ActiveMQ, you might use:<queue name>.
For Weblogic, you might use: jms/Queue.
Optional message selector to limit the messages read by the origin. By default, reads all messages.

entry.p: Additional JMS or JNDI configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the JMS or JNDI property name and value.
When you add a configuration property, enter the exact property name and value. The stage does not validate the property names or values.

row.entry:
Generates a single record for records that include multiple objects.
When not selected, the origin generates multiple records when a record includes multiple objects.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is for JMS Consumer origin and JMS Producer.

step.cmd: When using JMS credentials, on the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

cmd.draft-comment: Rows in this table are used by Kafka Consumer and SDC RPC to Kafka origins, also UDP to Kafka.

row.entry:
Connection string for the Kafka broker. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
To ensure a connection, enter a comma-separated list of additional broker URIs.

entry.p: Additional Kafka configuration properties to use. Using simple or bulk edit mode, click the Add icon to add properties. Define the Kafka property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by Kafka.
For information about enabling secure connections to Kafka, see .

cmd.draft-comment: RabbitMQ - Entire step used by Consumer, rows used by Producer

step.cmd: On the RabbitMQ tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
RabbitMQ URI.
Typically uses the following format: amqp:<host>:<port>/<virtualhost>.
RabbitMQ consumer tag. Leave empty to use an automatically generated consumer tag.

Generates a single record for each RabbitMQ message.
When not selected, the origin generates a record for each object in the message.

Additional RabbitMQ client configuration properties to use. To add properties, click Add and define the RabbitMQ client property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by RabbitMQ.
Enables the use of RabbitMQ credentials.

step.cmd: On the Credentials tab, enter the RabbitMQ credentials to use if you enabled credentials.
On the Queue tab, configure the following queue properties:
step.info:
These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.
Queue Property Description
Name Name of the queue to use or create.
Durable Creates a durable queue when selected.
The stage creates a durable queue by default.
Exclusive Creates an exclusive queue when selected. When exclusive, the queue allows only the to use it.
The stage creates an exclusive queue by default.
Auto-Delete Automatically deletes a queue after all consumers unsubscribe.
When used with an exclusive queue, the queue is automatically deleted when you stop the pipeline.
Declaration Properties Additional queue declaration properties to use.

step.cmd: On the Exchange tab, optionally configure the following binding properties for the bindings that you want to use. When no bindings are configured, the default exchange is used.
step.info:
These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.
Exchange Property Description
Name Binding name.
Type Binding type.
Durable Creates a durable exchange.
Auto-Delete Automatically deletes an exchange when all queues are finished using it.
Routing Key Routing key.
Leave empty to default to the queue name.
Declaration Properties Additional exchange properties to use.
Binding Properties Additional binding properties to use.

step.cmd: Optionally configure advanced options on the Advanced tab.
step.info: These properties directly correspond to RabbitMQ properties. For more information, see the RabbitMQ documentation.

Generally, you should use the defaults for these properties:
Advanced Property Description
Automatic Recovery Enabled Determines whether to attempt to reestablish a connection.
Network Recovery Interval Milliseconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a network connection.
Default is 5000.
Connection Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the connection to establish. Use 0 to opt out of a connection timeout.
Default is 0.
Handshake Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the handshake to complete.
Shutdown Timeout (ms) Milliseconds for the shutdown to complete.
Heartbeat Timeout (secs) Seconds to wait for a heartbeat to verify that RabbitMQ is up and the connection still available.
Use 0 to avoid requesting heartbeats. Default is 0.
Maximum Frame Size (bytes) Maximum frame size in bytes. Use for performance tuning.
Setting a larger value can improve throughput. Setting a smaller value can improve latency.
Use 0 for no limit. Default is 0.
Maximum Channel Number Maximum number of channels allowed.

cmd.draft-comment: The following is used for SDC RPC origins. Last two rows used by HTTP to Kafka origin

row.entry: Port number to listen to for data. Must match one of the port numbers associated with the SDC RPC destination that provides the data.
User-defined ID. Must match the RPC ID defined in the SDC RPC destination.

Enables the secure transfer of data using TLS (SSL).
To use encryption, both the origin and SDC RPC destination must be enabled for TLS.

Keystore file for SSL/TLS.
Must be stored in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES. For more information about environment variables, see .

cmd.draft-comment: O-UDPprops - whole step used by UDP Source. Rows in this table by UDP to Kafka. Data format bulletted list is also used by Configuring the Kafka Consumer > Datagram step and various origins that support Datagram. Some rows/entries used by Configuring the TCP Server origin.

step.cmd: On the UDP tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Port to listen to for data. Using simple or bulk edit mode, click the Add icon to list additional ports.To listen to a port below 1024, must be run by a user with root privileges. Otherwise, the operating system does not allow to bind to the port.

Specifies whether to use multiple receiver threads for each port. Using multiple receiver threads can improve performance.
You can use multiple receiver threads using epoll, which can be available when runs on recent versions of 64-bit Linux.

entry.ph: Number of receiver threads to use for each port. For example, if you configure two threads per port and configure the origin to use three ports, the origin uses a total of six threads.
entry.p: Use to increase the number of threads passing data to the origin when epoll is available on the machine.
Default is 1.

row.entry:
Data format passed by UDP:
collectd
NetFlow
syslog
Raw/separated data

Maximum number of messages to include in a batch and pass through the pipeline at one time. Honors values up to the maximum batch size.
Default is 1000. The default is 1000.
Milliseconds to wait before sending a partial or empty batch.

cmd.draft-comment: O-UDP-collectd - used by UDP Source and entries and ph used in Kafka Consumer.

step.cmd: On the collectd tab, define the following collectd properties:

entry.ph: Path to a user-provided types.db file. Overrides the default types.db file.
Converts the collectd high resolution time format interval and timestamp to UNIX time, in milliseconds.
Excludes the interval field from output record.
Path to an optional authentication file. Use an authentication file to accept signed and encrypted data.

cmd.draft-comment: O-Netflow9only used by UDP Source and probably UDP to Kafka?

step.cmd: For NetFlow 9 data, on the NetFlow 9 tab, configure the following properties:
step.info:
When processing earlier versions of NetFlow data, these properties are ignored.
Netflow 9 Property Description
Record Generation Mode
Determines the type of values to include in the record. Select one of the following options:
Raw Only
Interpreted Only
Both Raw and Interpreted
Max Templates in Cache The maximum number of templates to store in the template cache. For more information about templates, see .
Default is -1 for an unlimited cache size.
Template Cache Timeout (ms) The maximum number of milliseconds to cache an idle template. Templates unused for more than the specified time are evicted from the cache. For more information about templates, see .
Default is -1 for caching templates indefinitely.

cmd.draft-comment: Use this step for processors that have error handling - should be almost all.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: Use this step for processors that include a Stage Library field

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: Use the rows in this step for processors with event generation and error handling - currently the three scripting processors. Xref to the local Event Generation topic!

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Generates event records when events occur. Use for event handling.

Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline. Not valid for cluster pipelines.

cmd.draft-comment: Use the following step for processors without record handling - Field Remover, Record Deduplicator.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-NoStageLib - Use for destinations without stage libs, e.g. Local FS.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-StageLib-ReqField-EHandling - Use this step for destinations with stage library, req fields, and error handling. – Some rows are used by Hive Metastore. Also using these for executors that don't have event handling.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.

Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: 1stStep-D-E-EventHandling - Used by MapR Jobs executor, HDFS Metadata executor, Hadoop FS destination.

step.cmd: In the Properties panel, on the General tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Library version that you want to use.
Generates event records when events occur. Use for event handling.

Fields that must include data for the record to be passed into the stage. You might include fields that the stage uses.
Records that do not include all required fields are processed based on the error handling configured for the pipeline.

Conditions that must evaluate to TRUE to allow a record to enter the stage for processing. Click Add to create additional preconditions.
Records that do not meet all preconditions are processed based on the error handling configured for the stage.

Error record handling for the stage:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Stop Pipeline - Stops the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-Event - Used in Flume. Flume doesn't have other compression types, so it's not getting that note.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when writing data:
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema that you provide in the stage configuration.
In Record Header - Use the schema in the avroSchema record header attribute. Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.

Avro schema definition used to write the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Select to register a new Avro schema with the Confluent Schema Registry.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema or to register a new schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.

Avro schema subject to look up or to register in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject to look up has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.
Includes the schema in each event. Omitting the schema definition can improve performance, but requires the appropriate schema management to avoid losing track of the schema associated with the data.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-File - used in Amazon S3 and other file-based destinations that write avro.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when writing data:
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema that you provide in the stage configuration.
In Record Header - Use the schema in the avroSchema record header attribute. Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.
The destination includes the schema definition in each generated file.

Avro schema definition used to write the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Select to register a new Avro schema with the Confluent Schema Registry.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema or to register a new schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.

Avro schema subject to look up or to register in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject to look up has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-Mess - Used in all message destinations except for Kafka Producer - ie, Kinesis Producer, MapR Streams, Rabbit MQ Producer.

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when writing data:
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema that you provide in the stage configuration.
In Record Header - Use the schema in the avroSchema record header attribute. Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.

Avro schema definition used to write the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Select to register a new Avro schema with the Confluent Schema Registry.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema or to register a new schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.

Avro schema subject to look up or to register in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject to look up has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.

Includes the schema in each message. Omitting the schema definition can improve performance, but requires the appropriate schema management to avoid losing track of the schema associated with the data.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-AVRO-KAFKA used in Kafka Producer

step.cmd: For Avro data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Location of the Avro schema definition to use when writing data:
In Pipeline Configuration - Use the schema that you provide in the stage configuration.
In Record Header - Use the schema in the avroSchema record header attribute. Use only when the avroSchema attribute is defined for all records.
Confluent Schema Registry - Retrieve the schema from the Confluent Schema Registry.

Avro schema definition used to write the data.
You can optionally use the runtime:loadResource function to use a schema definition stored in a runtime resource file.
Select to register a new Avro schema with the Confluent Schema Registry.
Confluent Schema Registry URLs used to look up the schema or to register a new schema. To add a URL, click Add. Use the following format to enter the URL:http://<host name>:<port number>

Method used to look up the schema in the Confluent Schema Registry:
Subject - Look up the specified Avro schema subject.
Schema ID - Look up the specified Avro schema ID.

Avro schema subject to look up or to register in the Confluent Schema Registry.
If the specified subject to look up has multiple schema versions, the origin uses the latest schema version for that subject. To use an older version, find the corresponding schema ID, and then set the Look Up Schema By property to Schema ID.
Avro schema ID to look up in the Confluent Schema Registry.
Includes the schema in each message. If you configured Kafka Producer to embed the Avro schema ID in each message that it writes, clear this property.

The Avro compression type to use.
When using Avro compression, do not enable other compression available in the destination.

cmd.draft-comment: D-Binary - Used by Kafka Consumer and Amazon S3 dest.

step.cmd: For binary data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following property:

row.entry: Field that contains the binary data.

cmd.draft-comment: DelimProps: Use for the appropriate delimited destinations - currently Amazon S3, Flume, Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, and Kinesis Firehose:

step.cmd: For delimited data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Indicates whether to create a header line.

Replaces new line characters with the configured string.
Recommended when writing data as a single line of text.

String to replace each new line character. For example, enter a space to replace each new line character with a space.
Leave empty to remove the new line characters.

Delimiter character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
You can enter a Unicode control character using the format \uNNNN, where ​N is a hexadecimal digit from the numbers 0-9 or the letters A-F. For example, enter \u0000 to use the null character as the delimiter or \u2028 to use a line separator as the delimiter.
Default is the pipe character ( | ).

Escape character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
Default is the backslash character ( \ ).

Quote character for a custom delimiter format. Select one of the available options or use Other to enter a custom character.
Default is the quotation mark character ( " ).

cmd.draft-comment: JSONProps - Used for Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, Amazon S3, Kinesis Producer, and Kinesis Firehose.

step.cmd: For JSON data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following property:

row.entry:
Determines how JSON data is written:
JSON Array of Objects - Each file includes a single array. In the array, each element is a JSON representation of each record.
Multiple JSON Objects - Each file includes multiple JSON objects. Each object is a JSON representation of a record.

cmd.draft-comment:
D-PROTO-props - used by all protobuf destinations EXCEPT for Google Pub/Sub Publisher which as one additional property....that table is below.
NOTE: when making changes, make sure to make any related ones to BOTH origin tables.

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when writing data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.

cmd.draft-comment: D-PROTO-props-PubSub used by the Google Pub/Sub Publisher destination only, it has one additional property

step.cmd: For protobuf data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Descriptor file (.desc) to use. The descriptor file must be in the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES.
For information about generating the descriptor file, see .

The fully-qualified name for the message type to use when writing data.
Use the following format: <package name>.<message type>. Use a message type defined in the descriptor file.
Writes a delimiter after each message.

cmd.draft-comment: TextProps - Using for Hadoop FS, Kafka Producer, and Amazon S3.

step.cmd: For text data, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Field that contains the text data to be written. All data must be incorporated into the specified field.

Characters to use to separate records. Use any valid Java string literal. For example, when writing to Windows, you might use \r\n to separate records.
By default, the destination uses \n.
Insert Record Separator if No Text

When a record does not include the text field, inserts the configured record separator string to create an empty line.
When not selected, records without the text field are discarded.

info.draft-comment: D-WHOLEFile-props - Whole table used by Hadoop FS, Local FS, and MapR FS. Rows used by S3 and Azure Data Lake Store

step.cmd: For whole files, on the Data Format tab, configure the following properties:

entry.p: Expression to use for the file names.
For tips on how to name files based on input file names, see .

row.entry:
Action to take when a file of the same name already exists in the output directory. Use one of the following options:
Send to Error - Handles the record based on stage error record handling.
Overwrite - Overwrites the existing file.

Includes checksum information in whole file event records.
Use only when the destination generates event records.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used by message-based destinations that write XML data - JMS Producer and Kafka Producer for now:

step.cmd: For XML data, on the XML tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Adds indentation to make the resulting XML document easier to read. Increases the record size accordingly.

Validates
Regardless of whether you validate the XML schema, the destination requires the record in a specific format. For more information, see .
The XML schema to use to validate records.

cmd.draft-comment: FS-OutputFiles - Hadoop FS, Local FS and MapR FS conref rows/partial rows in the table. Data Lake Store also steals rows and entries from here.

step.cmd: On the Output Files tab, configure the following options:

row.entry:
Maximum time that an output file can remain idle. After no records are written to a file for this amount of time, the destination closes the file. Enter a time in seconds or use the MINUTES or HOURS constant in an expression to define the time increment.
Use -1 to set no limit. Default is 1 hour, defined as follows: ${1 * HOURS}.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Output file type:
Text files
Sequence files
Whole files - Select when using the whole file data format.

Format of data to be written. Use one of the following options:
Avro
Binary
Delimited
JSON
Protobuf
Text
Whole File

Prefix to use for output files. Use when writing to a directory that receives files from other sources.
Uses the prefix sdc-${sdc:id()} by default. The prefix evaluates to sdc-< ID>.
The ID is stored in the following file: $SDC_DATA/sdc.id.

Suffix to use for output files, such as txt or json. When used, the destination adds a period and the configured suffix as follows: <filename>.<suffix>.
You can include periods within the suffix, but do not start the suffix with a period. Forward slashes are not allowed.
Not available for the whole file data format.
Indicates that the target directory is defined in record headers. Use only when the targetDirectory header attribute is defined for all records.

Template for creating output directories. You can use constants, field values, and datetime variables.
Output directories are created based on the smallest datetime variable in the template.
Time zone for the destination system. Used to resolve datetimes in the directory template and evaluate where records are written.

Time basis to use for creating output directories and writing records to the directories. Use one of the following expressions:
${time:now()} - Uses the processing time as the time basis.
${record:value(<date field path>)} - Uses the time associated with the record as the time basis.

Maximum number of records to be written to an output file. Additional records are written to a new file.
Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Maximum size of an output file. Additional records are written to a new file.
Use 0 to opt out of this property.
Not available when using the whole file data format.

Compression type for output files:
None
gzip
bzip2
Snappy
LZ4
Other
Do not use with Avro data. To compress Avro data, use the Avro Compression Codec property on the Data Formats tab.
Full class name of the other compression codec that you want to use.

Compression type for sequence files when using a compression codec:
Block Compression
Record Compression

Checks the record header for the roll header attribute and closes the current file when the roll attribute exists.
Can be used with Max Records in a File and Max File Size to close files.

Name of the roll header attribute.
Default is roll.

When you start the pipeline, the destination tries writing to the configured directory template to validate permissions. The pipeline does not start if validation fails.Do not use this option when the directory template uses expressions to represent the entire directory.
Determines whether the destination performs file recovery after an unexpected stop of the pipeline.

cmd.draft-comment: The following step is used by the Event Hub destination, rows by the origin.

step.cmd: On the Event Hub tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: The name of the namespace that contains the event hub that you want to use.

The policy name associated with the namespace.
To retrieve the policy name, when logged into the Azure portal, navigate to your namespace and event hub, and then click Shared Access Policies for a list of policies.
When appropriate, you can use the default shared access key policy, RootManageSharedAccessKey.

One of the connection string keys associated with the specified shared access policy.
To retrieve a connection string key, after accessing the list of shared access policies, click the policy name, and then copy the Connection String - Primary Key value.
The value typically begins with "Endpoint".

step.info: For more information about Microsoft Azure Event Hub, see the Event Hub documentation.

cmd.draft-comment: Elasticsearch properties - all used by Elasticsearch destination. Most used by Elasticsearch origin. All but Default Operation and Unsupported Operation Handling used by Configuring a Pipeline > Error handling. Default Operation and Unsupported Operation Handling descriptions used by Kudu, JDBC Producer and JDBC Tee

step.cmd: On the Elasticsearch tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: HTTP URI used to connect to the cluster. Use the following format: <host>:<port>
Additional HTTP parameters that you want to send as query string parameters to Elasticsearch. Enter the exact parameter name and value expected by Elasticsearch.

entry.p: Detects additional nodes in the cluster based on the configured Cluster URI.
Selecting this property is the equivalent to setting the client.transport.sniff Elasticsearch property to true.
Use only when the Data Collector shares the same network as the Elasticsearch cluster. Do not use for Elastic Cloud or Docker clusters.

row.entry: Specifies whether security is enabled on the Elasticsearch cluster.

entry.p:
Time basis to use for writing to time-based indexes. Use one of the following expressions:
${time:now()} - Uses the processing time as the time basis. The processing time is the time associated with the running the pipeline.
An expression that calls a field and resolves to a datetime value, such as ${record:value(<date field path>)}. Uses the datetime result as the time basis.
When the Index property does not include datetime variables, you can ignore this property.
Default is ${time:now()}.

row.entry: Time zone for the destination system. Used to resolve datetimes in time-based indexes.

Index for the generated documents. Enter an index name or an expression that evaluates to the index name.
For example, if you enter customer as the index, the destination writes the document within the customer index.
If you use datetime variables in the expression, make sure to configure the time basis appropriately. For details about datetime variables, see .

Mapping type for the generated documents. Enter the mapping type, an expression that evaluates to the mapping type, or a field that includes the mapping type.
For example, if you enter user as the mapping type, the destination writes the document with a user mapping type.

Expression that evaluates to the ID for the generated documents. When you do not specify an ID, Elasticsearch creates an ID for each document.
By default, the destination allows Elasticsearch to create the ID.

Optional parent ID for the generated documents. Enter a parent ID or an expression that evaluates to the parent ID.
Use to establish a parent-child relationship between documents in the same index.

Optional custom routing value for the generated documents. Enter a routing value or an expression that evaluates to the routing value.
Elasticsearch routes a document to a particular shard in an index based on the routing value defined for the document. You can define a custom value for each document. If you don’t define a custom routing value, Elasticsearch uses the parent ID (if defined) or the document ID as the routing value.

entry.p: Character encoding of the data to be processed.

row.entry: Default CRUD operation to perform if the sdc.operation.type record header attribute is not set.

Action to take when the CRUD operation type defined in the sdc.operation.type record header attribute is not supported:
Discard - Discards the record.
Send to Error - Sends the record to the pipeline for error handling.
Use Default Operation - Writes the record to the destination system using the default operation.

step.cmd: If you enabled security, on the Security tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Elasticsearch username and password.
Enter the username and password using the following syntax:<username>:<password>

entry.p: Location of the truststore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.truststore.path Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.
Password for the truststore file.
Configuring this property is the equivalent to configuring the shield.ssl.truststore.password Elasticsearch property.
Not necessary for Elastic Cloud clusters.

cmd.draft-comment: the following are used by Google Pub Sub and rows by Pipeline > Write to Error

step.cmd: On the Pub/Sub tab, configure the following property:

row.entry: Google Pub/Sub topic ID to write messages to.

step.cmd: On the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Google Pub/Sub project ID to connect to.

Credentials provider to use to connect to Google Pub/Sub:
Default credentials provider
Service account credentials file (JSON)

When using a Google Cloud service account credentials file, path to the file that the destination uses to connect to Google Pub/Sub. The credentials file must be a JSON file.
Enter a path relative to the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES, or enter an absolute path.

cmd.draft-comment: the following are used by Google Cloud Storage and rows by Pipeline > Write to Error

step.cmd: On the GCS tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry: Common prefix that determines where objects are written.

Optional partition prefix to specify the partition to use.
Use a specific partition prefix or define an expression that evaluates to a partition prefix.
When using datetime variables in the expression, be sure to configure the time basis for the stage.

entry.p: Time zone for the destination system. Used to resolve datetimes in a time-based partition prefix.

Time basis to use for writing to a time-based bucket or partition prefix. Use one of the following expressions:
${time:now()} - Uses the processing time as the time basis in conjunction with the specified Data Time Zone.
An expression that calls a field and resolves to a datetime value, such as ${record:value(<date field path>)}. Uses the time associated with the record as the time basis, adjusted for the specified Data Time Zone.
When the Partition Prefix property has no time component, you can ignore this property.
Default is ${time:now()}.

row.entry:
Defines a prefix for object names written by the destination. By default, object names start with "sdc" as follows: sdc-<UUID>.
Not required for the whole file data format.

Suffix to use for object names, such as txt or json. When used, the destination adds a period and the configured suffix as follows: <object name>.<suffix>.
You can include periods within the suffix, but do not start the suffix with a period. Forward slashes are not allowed.
Not available for the whole file data format.

Compresses files with gzip before writing to Google Cloud Storage.
Not available for the whole file data format.

step.cmd: On the Credentials tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Credentials provider to use to connect:
Default credentials provider
Service account credentials file (JSON)

When using a Google Cloud service account credentials file, path to the file that the origin uses to connect to Google Cloud Storage. The credentials file must be a JSON file.
Enter a path relative to the resources directory, $SDC_RESOURCES, or enter an absolute path.

cmd.draft-comment: FS-LateRecords - for Hadoop FS and Local FS

step.cmd: On the Late Records tab, configure the following properties:

info.note: These properties are relevant for a time basis based on the time of a record. If you use processing time as the time basis, set the late record time limit to one second.

row.entry:
Time limit for output directories to accept data.
You can enter a time in seconds, or use the expression to enter a time in hours. You can also use MINUTES in the default expression to define the time in minutes.

Determines how to handle late records:
Send to error - Sends the record to the stage for error handling.
Send to late records file - Sends the record to a late records file.

Template for creating late record directories. You can use constants, field values, and datetime variables.
Output directories are created based on the smallest datetime variable in the template.

cmd.draft-comment: KafkaConfig - used for the Kafka Producer - Kafka tab properties. Rows in the table are used for Configuring a Pipeline, error handling > Write to Kafka, and DPM chapter > Aggregated Statistics > Configuring a Pipeline to Aggregate Statistics. -- Message per Batch also used by RabbitMQ Producer. Some rows also used by MapR Streams Producer.

step.cmd: On the Kafka tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Connection string for the Kafka broker. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
To ensure a connection, enter a comma-separated list of additional broker URI.
Evaluates an expression at runtime to determine the topic to use for each record.

Topic to use.
Not available when using runtime topic resolution.
Expression used to determine where each record is written when using runtime topic resolution. Use an expression that evaluates to a topic name.

List of valid topic names to write to when using runtime topic resolution. Use to avoid writing to invalid topics. Records that resolve to invalid topic names are passed to the stage for error handling.
Use an asterisk (*) to allow writing to any topic name. By default, all topic names are valid.

Strategy to use to write to partitions:
Round Robin - Takes turns writing to different partitions.
Random - Writes to partitions randomly.
Expression - Uses an expression to write data to different partitions. Writes records to the partitions specified by the results of the expression.
Default - Uses an expression to extract a partition key from the record. Writes records to partitions based on a hash of the partition key.

Expression to use with the default or expression partition strategy.
When using the default partition strategy, specify an expression that returns the partition key from the record. The expression must evaluate to a string value.
When using the expression partition strategy, specify an expression that evaluates to the partition where you want each record written. Partition numbers start with 0. The expression must evaluate to a numeric value.
For each batch, writes the records to each partition as a single message.

Additional Kafka properties to use. Using simple or bulk edit mode, click the Add icon and define the Kafka property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by Kafka. Do not use the broker.list property.
For information about enabling secure connections to Kafka, see .

Method used to serialize the Kafka message key when the configured data format is Avro.
Set to Confluent to embed the Avro schema ID in each message that Kafka Producer writes.

Method used to serialize the Kafka message value when the configured data format is Avro.
Set to Confluent to embed the Avro schema ID in each message that Kafka Producer writes.

cmd.draft-comment: MapRStreams-props - used by MapR Streams Producer and Info tag used by Configuring a Pipeline > Write to MapR Streams.

step.cmd: On the MapR Streams Producer tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Additional configuration properties to use. Using simple or bulk edit mode, click the Add icon and define the MapR Streams property name and value.
Use the property names and values as expected by MapR.
You can use MapR Streams properties and the set of Kafka properties supported by MapR Streams.

cmd.draft-comment: RPCdest - Used for Config RPC Dest and pipeline error handling > Write to pipeline.

step.cmd: On the RPC tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Connection information for the destination pipeline to continue processing data. Use the following format: <host>:<port>.
Use a single RPC connection for each destination pipeline. Using simple or bulk edit mode, add additional connections as needed.
Use the port number when you configure the SDC RPC origin that receives the data.
User-defined ID to allow the destination to pass data to an SDC RPC origin. Use this ID in all SDC RPC origins to process data from the destination.
Verifies the host in the SDC RPC origin keystore file.

cmd.draft-comment: RPCdestAdv - Used in RPC destination & pipeline error config - write to pipeline.

step.cmd: On the Advanced tab, configure the following properties:

row.entry:
Number of times the destination tries to write a batch to the SDC RPC origin.
When the destination cannot write the batch within the configured number of retries, it fails the batch.
Default is 3.

Milliseconds to wait before retrying writing a batch to the SDC RPC origin.
The value that you enter increases exponentially after each retry, until it reaches the maximum wait time of 5 minutes. For example, if you set the back off period to 10, the destination attempts the first retry after waiting 10 milliseconds, attempts the second retry after waiting 100 milliseconds, and attempts the third retry after waiting 1,000 milliseconds.
Set to 0 to retry immediately.
Default is 0.

Milliseconds to establish a connection to the SDC RPC origin.
The destination retries the connection based on the Retries Per Batch property.
Default is 5000 milliseconds.

Milliseconds to wait for the SDC RPC origin to read data from a batch.
The destination retries the write based on the Retries Per Batch property.
Default is 2000 milliseconds.
Enables the destination to use compression to pass data to the SDC RPC origin. Enabled by default.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in "Step 1. Install the StreamSets Custom Service Descriptor" in the Installation chapter and the Upgrade chapter.

step.cmd: Use the following URL to download the CSD from the StreamSets website: .
Copy the CSD file to the Local Descriptor Repository Path. By default, the path is /opt/cloudera/csd.
step.info: To verify the path to use, in Cloudera Manager, click Administration Settings . In the navigation panel, select the Custom Service Descriptors category. Place the CSD file in the path configured for Local Descriptor Repository Path.

step.cmd: Set the file ownership to cloudera-scm:cloudera-scm with permission 644.
step.info: For example: chown cloudera-scm:cloudera-scm /opt/cloudera/csd/STREAMSETS*.jar chmod 644 /opt/cloudera/csd/STREAMSETS*.jar

step.cmd: Use one of the following commands to restart Cloudera Manager Server:
step.info: For Ubuntu 14.04, CentOS 6, or Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6: service cloudera-scm-server restartFor Ubuntu 16.04, CentOS 7, or Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7: systemctl restart cloudera-scm-server

step.cmd: In Cloudera Manager, to restart the Cloudera Management Service, click Home Status . To the right of Cloudera Management Service, click the Menu icon and select Restart.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used in "Step 2. Manually Install the Parcel and Checksum Files (Optional)" used in the Installation and Upgrade chapters.

step.cmd: Download the StreamSets parcel and related checksum file for the Cloudera Manager Server operating system from the following location:
Copy the StreamSets parcel and checksum files to the Cloudera Manager Local Parcel Repository Path.
step.info: By default, the path is /opt/cloudera/parcel-repo.

To verify the path to use, click Administration Settings . In the navigation panel, select the Parcels category. Place the StreamSets parcel file in the path configured for Local Parcel Repository Path.

cmd.draft-comment: The following steps are used for the Enabling SSL topics for the MongoDB origin and destination, and for the Configuring Secure Connections to LDAP topic in Configuration chapter

step.cmd: In the Advanced tab for the stage, select the SSL Enabled property.
Define the following options in the SDC_JAVA_OPTS environment variable in the Data Collector environment configuration file located in the $SDC_DIST/libexec directory:

info.p: For example, define the options as follows:export SDC_JAVA_OPTS="-Djavax.net.ssl.trustStore=<path to truststore file> -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=<password> -Xmx1024m -Xms1024m -server ${SDC_JAVA_OPTS}"
Or to secure the password, save the password in a text file and then define the truststore password option as follows: -Djavax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword=$(cat passwordfile.txt)

step.cmd: Restart to enable the changes.

cmd.draft-comment: Cluster doc shared steps –
First checkpoint for Kafka and Mesos YARN Streaming, Info steps conrefed by other versions.

step.cmd: To enable checkpoint metadata storage, grant the user defined in the user environment variable write permission on /user/$SDC_USER.
step.info: The user environment variable defines the system user used to run Data Collector as a service. The file that defines the user environment variable depends on your operating system. For more information, see .

For example, say the user environment variable is defined as sdc and the cluster does not use Kerberos. Then you might use the following commands to create the directory and configure the necessary write permissions:$sudo -u hdfs hadoop fs -mkdir /user/sdc $sudo -u hdfs hadoop fs -chown sdc /user/sdc

cmd.draft-comment: Mesos version of above, removed Kerberos from example.

step.cmd: To enable checkpoint metadata storage, grant the user defined in the user environment variable write permission on /user/$SDC_USER.
step.info: For example, say $SDC_USER is defined as sdc. Then you might use the following commands to create the directory and configure the necessary write permissions:

cmd.draft-comment: Spark Submit Script step - whole step used by Kafka Yarn Streaming, Kafka Mesos and Mapr Streaming use parts of it.

step.cmd: If necessary, specify the location of the spark-submit script.
step.info: assumes that the spark-submit script used to submit job requests to Spark Streaming is located in the following directory: /usr/bin/spark-submit
If the script is not in this directory, use the SPARK_SUBMIT_YARN_COMMAND environment variable to define the location of the script.
The location of the script may differ depending on the Spark version and distribution that you use.

info.ph: For example, when using CDH Spark 2.1, the spark-submit script is in the following directory by default: /usr/bin/spark2-submit. Then, you might use the following command to define the location of the script:

info.note: If you change the location of the spark-submit script, you must restart to capture the change.

cmd.draft-comment: MapR Cluster Batch and HDFS (cluster batch)

step.cmd: Grant the user defined in the user environment variable write permission on /user/$SDC_USER.
If YARN is configured to use Kerberos authentication, configure to use Kerberos authentication.
step.info: When you configure Kerberos authentication for , you enable to use Kerberos and define the principal and keytab. For cluster pipelines, enter an absolute path to the keytab when configuring . Standalone pipelines do not require an absolute path.
Once enabled, automatically uses the Kerberos principal and keytab to connect to any YARN cluster that uses Kerberos.

cmd.draft-comment: Just the bullets in this step used I think:

step.cmd: To enable to submit YARN jobs, perform one of the following tasks:

ul.li: On YARN, set the min.user.id to a value equal to or lower than the user ID associated with the user ID, typically named "sdc".
On YARN, add the user name, typically "sdc", to the allowed.system.users property.

cmd.draft-comment: The following two steps are reused in the Tarball and RPM upgrade section - Update the Configuration Files

step.cmd: Compare the previous and new versions of the sdc.properties file, and update the new file as needed with the same customized property values.
Compare the previous and new versions of the remaining files, and update the new files as needed with the same customized property values:

ul.li: The appropriate realm.properties file, based on the authentication type that you use.

Vault properties file
As of version 2.7.0.0, most of the Vault configuration properties have been moved to the new credential stores properties file. The properties use the same name, with an added "credentialStore.vault.config" prefix. If you are upgrading from a version earlier than 2.7.0.0, copy any values that you customized in the previous Vault properties file into the same property names in the credential stores properties file.

cmd.draft-comment: Use in Starting Pipelines with Parameters in the Pipeline Configuration chapter and the Pipeline Maintenance chapter

step.cmd: From the pipeline canvas, click the More icon, and then click Start with Parameters.
step.info:
If Start with Parameters is not enabled, the pipeline is not valid.
The Start with Parameters dialog box lists all parameters defined for the pipeline and their default values.

step.cmd: Override any default values with the values you want to use for this pipeline run.
Click Start.
